description.narrative: Accelerator Lab PRY busca ser un espacio de descubrimiento, experimentación, aprendizaje, e innovación para el desarrollo social. El laboratorio busca construir la mayor red de aprendizaje del mundo en torno al desarrollo.

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative:
Output 1: UNDP Country Offices and partners will have increased capability for scanning, sensemaking and experimentation for sustainable development solutions in 60 developing countries.
1.1 Number of new data sources used at Country Office level. 1.2 Diversity of different data sources used 1.3 Number of sustainable development solutions identified and documented 1.4 Variety of innovation methods used to test and iterate over the different hypotheses.
Output 2: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations, national policy and/or local markets.
2.1 Learning the Accelerator Lab Network shares with a public audience (outside of UNDP) 2.2 Number of lab insights, processes or products which are taken up by governments or other partners 2.3 Proportion of partners and governments that increase their take up of the innovation methods included in the Accelerator Lab Network suite 2.4 Proportion of UNDP Country Office programming influenced by the Accelerator Lab Network’s work and methodologies.
Output 3: A core global level result will be that a global learning and scaling network is established and functioning.
3.1 Size and density of the network effects among the Accelerator Labs 3.2 Number of new models, approaches, and insights documented and disseminated throughout the network. 3.3 Engagement of the broader Development ecosystem with published learnings from the Accelerator Lab Network. 3.4 Amount of influence the learnings and methods of the Accelerator Lab Networks have on the discourse of the broader Development ecosystem.
Output 2: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations, national policy and/or local markets.
2.1 Learning the Accelerator Lab Network shares with a public audience (outside of UNDP) 2.2 Number of lab insights, processes or products which are taken up by go

comment.narrative:
Output 1:
1.1 10 new data sources per year. 1.2 9 different type of data sources per year. 1.3 50 new potential solutions per lab per year. 1.4 10 innovation methods per Action Plan.
Output 2:
2.1 At least 8 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year. 2.2 At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart. 2.3 At least one government entity or partner has adopted an accelerator lab method. 2.4 At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects.
Output 3:
3.1 The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network. 48 interaction per year. 3.2 50% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. 3.3 The Accelerator Lab Network’s work is featured at least 3 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account. 3.4 Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 10 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.

Output 1:
1.1 10 new data sources per year: 1) Primary Data: Surveys, Micro-Surveys, Interviews, Culural Probes, Crowdsource, Randomized Controlled Trial, Blogs and Reports 2) Secondary Data: Offcial Data, International Organization Reports 1.2 9 different type of data sources per year: 1) Survey and Micro-Surveys and Interviews: 2) Official Data: Permanent Household Survey 3) Crowdsource: Social Innovation Health Initiatives (CONACYT Challenge), Wendá Platform: Apparel Cluster in Yaguarón, Wood Furniture in Central 4) Cultural Probe: Domestic Workers 5) Geospatial: San Francisco’s Informal waste pickers shadowing exercise and recycling routes visualization. 6) Randomized Controlled Trials: Domestic Work Formalization (Asunción) – LabMTESS, Apparel Flexible Manufacturing (Yaguarón) - Wendá, Food Safety (San Juan Nepomuceno) – Wendá 7) impact Evaluation: “Mi Barrio Sin Residuos” – local recycling campaign develop by a CO Project and Coca Cola (PARESA) 1.3 50 new potential solutions per lab per year: 50 solutions mapped uploaded to the solutions mappers platform 1.4 10 innovation methods per Action Plan: 1) Data Analysis 2) Solutions Mapping 3) Human Centered Design 4) Behavioral insights 5) Collective intelligence 6) Randomized Controlled Trials 7) Positive Deviance 8) Geospatial Analysis 9) Transformation in developing organizations 10) Visualisation & mapping
Output 2:
2.1 At least 8 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year: 1) Recycling as a collective action dilemma: how can we address recycling challenges in Asuncion? (English / Spanish) 2) Prototyping a new generation of Eco-Friendly Wastebaskets (English / Spanish) 3) Moirũ: what we learned integrating community participation and social innovation (English / Spanish) 4) Informal Barriers: An initial diagnosis of informal employment in the construction sector from LabMTESS (English / Spanish) 5) The story of Kuña Jero: when need knocks on your door (English / Spanish) 6) Guerrilla Verde and the impact of organizations in los bañados (English / Spanish) 7) Semilla Róga and the women activists behind it (English / Spanish) 8) Semillas Nativas: an ancient practice, preserved by brave women (English / Spanish) 9) Mbokaja Poty producers committee: from meetings under the trees, to empowering an entire district (English / Spanish) 10) A day in the life of Asuncions waste pickers - Part I (English / Spanish) 11) A day in the life of Asuncions waste pickers - Part II (English / Spanish) 12) Temporary work, information and the roots of informality in Paraguay’s construction sector (English / Spanish) 13) Domestic work: a challenge and a learning agenda for Paraguay (English / Spanish) 14) Mapping social capital, economic vulnerability, and collective action in times of COVID 19- Part 1 (English / Spanish) 15) Mi Barrio sin Residuos: cómo inyectar innovación al reciclaje (Spanish) 16) Diagnóstico del Empleo Informal en la Cadena de la Construcción del Área Metropolitana de Asunción (Spanish)
2.2 At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart: 1) Wendá Producción Flexible y Alimentación para Todos 2) Diálogos Cientificos 3) Desviaciones postivias
Presidential Delivery Unit; Employment Observatory of the Ministry of Labor, Employment and Social Security; General Directorate of Entrepreneurship of the Ministry of Industry and Commerce; Fund for Excellence in Education and Research (FEEI); Ministry of Health and Social Welfare
2.3 At least one government entity or partner has adopted an accelerator lab method: 1) During 2021, together with the National Innovation Strategy (ENI) team, we carried out 2 complete learning cycles on Apparel Flexible Manufacturing and another on Food Safety, both cycles were developed with methodological support from AccLab to ENI’s technical team and consultants. 2) We co-design together with the National Science and Technology Council, a social innovation challenge, based on a previous experience of the AccLab, the community social innovation challenge: Moiru (2020)
2.4 At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects: Paraguay’s CO has 3 large portfolios including: Democratic Governance, Inclusive Development and Sustainable Development, in addition to cross-cutting areas such as Comms, Monitoring and Evaluation, HR and Gender. 1) The AccLab carried out the impact assessment of the initiative My Neighborhood Without Waste developed by Coca Cola, the organization Soluciones Ecologicas and the Asuncion Green City of the Americas (CO project), it represents an important input for the design of version 2.0 to be developed during 2022. 2) The AccLab, together with a project of the Democratic Governance portfolio and the CEAMSO organization, are carrying out an intervention for a participatory process of citizen control regarding the provision of food to children in schools. 3) The AccLab provided methodological feedback for the design of Terms of Reference for activities and service providers for the Small Grants Program and the National Human Development Report 2022, and participated in the monitoring of these services.
Output 3:
3.1 The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network. 48 interaction per year: One a week for Drop-In calls and biweekly calls by role (solution mappers, explorers, and experimenters) 3.2 50% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related: 1) Data Analysis; 2) Solutions Mapping 3) Human Centered Design; 4) Behavioral insights; 5) Collective intelligence; 6) Randomized Controlled Trials; 7) Positive Deviance; 8) Geospatial Analysis; 9) Transformation in developing organizations; 10) Visualisation & mapping 3.3 The Accelerator Lab Network’s work is featured at least 3 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account: The AccLab activities are shared through the CO social networks (twitter, facebook, instagram and linkedin) with a minimum monthly frequency, the content includes: blogs, workshops and field activities, calls, and results presentations tagging allied institutions and organizations. 3.4 Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 10 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem: Some of the strategies developed in order to increase the reach of our social media publications are: the creation of differentiated profiles for our main learning loops, such as LabMTESS (developed with the Ministry of Labor) and Wendá (developed with the National Innovation Strategy (ENI) dependent on the Management Unit of the Presidency of the Republic), the publications of these accounts are reposted by the UNDP accounts, another important practice described in the previous indicator is to tag institutions, organizations and main collaborators in each publication, of which we could list: • Private Sector: Coca Cola, Soluciones Ecológicas, Hult Prize • National Government: CONACYT, National Innovation Strategy (ENI), Ministry of Labor (MTESS), Ministry of Industry and Commerce (MIC), Presidential Delivery Unit, ODS National Commission, Science and Education Ministry (MEC) • Local Government: Municipality of Asunción, Yaguarón, • Other UN Agencies: ILO, UN Development, UNICEF, Global Laboratory Network • Civil Society: Tesai Reka, CEAMSO, Paraguay Ahora • Recognized Professionals: Mariana Salgado (Argentina-Finland), Daniel Aldrich (USA), Cyrus Samii (EGAP), David Riveros (Local NGO, Reaccion), Guillermo Sequera (Ministry of Health), Joaquin Collao (Public Sector Innovation Consultant GobLab Chile)

Output 1: 1.1 2 new sources of data per year. 1.2 3 different type of data sources per year. 1.3 20 new potential solutions per lab per year. 1.4 2 innovation methods per Action Plan.
Output 2: 2.1 3 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year. 2.2 At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart. 2.3 At least one government entity or partner has learned about Accelerator lab methods. 2.4 At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects.
Output 3: 3.1 The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network. 48 interaction per year: 3.2 5% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. 3.3 The Accelerator Lab Network´s work is featured at least 2 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account. 3.4 Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 2 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.

Output 1:
1.1 2 new sources of data per year: 1) Primary Data – Surveys and Interviews, Workshops 2) Secondary Data – Official Data 1.2 3 different type of data sources per year: 1) Surveys and Interviews: Sensemaking CO, Paraguay’s Innovation Ecosystem; 2) Workshops for the identification of the National Innovation Challenges; 3) Official Data: Permanent Household Survey, Integrated Social Information System (SIIS) 1.3 20 new potential solutions per lab per year: 20 solutions mapped uploaded to the solutions mappers platform 1.4 2 innovation methods per Action Plan: 1) Solutions Mapping 2) Human Centered Design
Output 2:
2.1 3 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year: 1) Learning for Development: How do we know what works? (English / Spanish) 2.2 At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart: 1) We accompany the methodological process of identifying innovation challenges at the national level with the Presidential Delivery Unit. 2) Together with a CO inclusive development project and the Social Policy Delivery Unit we carried out the process of evaluating the results of proposals for territorial development in the city of Carayao. 2.3 At least one government entity or partner has learned about Accelerator lab methods: National Innovation Strategy close collaboration for their workshops design for the identification and validations of national innovation challenges across the country. 2.4 At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects: Paraguay’s CO has 3 large portfolios including: Democratic Governance, Inclusive Development and Sustainable Development, in addition to cross-cutting areas such as Comms, Monitoring and Evaluation, HR and Gender. The AccLab spent the first few months getting to know the projects within each of these portfolios. We designed a sensemaking process based on the CPD, and other strategic documents of UNDP and at the national level in order to define the frontier challenges on which the AccLab would work. Some examples of joint work during the AccLab first months were: 1) Together with the Asuncion Green City of the Americas project, we applied for an exercise on Collective Intelligence on waste management led by Nesta and the Global Lab. 2) We methodologically support the process of application and selection of initiatives that participate locally in the Small Grants Program (SGP), facilitating collaborative spaces and workshops
Output 3:
3.1 The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network. 48 interaction per year: One a week for Drop-In calls and biweekly calls by role (solution mappers, explorers, and experimenters) 3.2 5% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related: 1) Solutions Mapping 2) Human Centered Design 3.3 The Accelerator Lab Network´s work is featured at least 2 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account: The AccLab works along with the CO Communication Team providing relevant information about its current line of work and collaborations with the CO Projects (Carayao, Asunción Green City of the Americas) 3.4 Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 2 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem: On its first months the AccLab initiate close collaboration with the National Innovation Strategy and the government new social protecting scheme..

Output 1: 1.1 5 new data sources per year. 1.2 6 different type of data sources per year. 1.3 35 new potential solutions per lab per year. 1.4 5 innovation methods per Action Plan.
Output 2: 2.1 At least 6 blogs or other (substantial) media posts published per year. 2.2 At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart. 2.3 At least one government entity or partner has adopted an accelerator lab method. 2.4 At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects.
Output 3: 3.1 The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network. 48 interaction per year. 3.2 25% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. The Accelerator Lab Networks work is featured at least 3 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. 3.3 The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account. 3.4 Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 5 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.

Output 1:
1.1 5 new data sources per year: 1) Primary Data: Surveys, Micro-Surveys, Interviews, Culural Probes, Crowdsource, Randomized Controlled Trial, Blogs and Reports 2) Secondary Data: Offcial Data, International Organization Reports 1.2 6 different type of data sources per year: 1) Survey and Micro-Surveys and Interviews: Social Ties, Informal Waste pickers 2) Cultural Probes: Informal Construction Workers 3) Crowdsource: Mapa Social, Wendá Platform, Social Innovation Challenge (Moiru) 4) Randomized Controlled Trials: Focus on information access on formalization for workers in the construction sector 5) Official Data: Permanent Household Survey, Paraguay’s Central Bank, Population Census 2011, Ministry of Public Health, Time Use Survey 2016, International Cooperation Reports (OIT, FAO, IDB) 1.3 35 new potential solutions per lab per year: 35 solutions mapped uploaded to the solutions mappers platform 1.4 5 innovation methods per Action Plan: 1) Solutions Mapping 2) Human Centered Design 3) Sensemaking 4) Collective intelligence 5) Randomized Controlled Trials 6) Co-creation 7) Prototyping
Output 2:
2.1 At least 6 blogs or other (substantial) media posts published per year: 1) Solutions Mapping in a Crisis Context (English / Spanish) 2) La ENI frente al COVID (Spanish) 3) ¿Cómo funciona un laboratorio de aceleración del PNUD en Paraguay? (Spanish) 4) Public innovation from within: the Ministry of Labor’s new Participatory Laboratory for Employment Formalization (English / Spanish) 5) WENDÁ: articulación, colaboración e innovación ante el COVID-19 (Spanish) 6) In a sea of solutions, how can we identify what truly works? Constructing hypotheses for development (English / Spanish) 7) Leveraging “Collective Intelligence” to Improve Asuncion’s Waste Management (English / Spanish) 2.2 At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart: Our portfolio includes the participation of the public sector, civil society and academia: 1) Wendá, project developed to strengthen the local innovation ecosystem through the institutionalization of the National Innovation Strategy (ENI) (dependent of the Presidential Delivery Unit), with a focus on citizen resilience to COVID-19. 2) Moiru: Social Innovation Challenge focused on promoting current initiatives focused on SDGs 2 and 5 carried out in collaboration and support of the SDG Paraguay Commission (Ministry of Foreign Affairs) and the National Innovation Strategy (ENI) 3) LabMTESS: Public Innovation Laboratory focused on the formalization of employment carried out in collaboration with the Employment Observatory of the Ministry of Labor, Employment and Social Security (MTESS) 4) Social Ties: Preliminary study on the different types of interpersonal networks and economic vulnerability, with the Northeastern University. 5) Todos por Paraguay: Crowdfunding campaign developed in coordination with public institutions (Ministry of Health), private sector (Global Compact) and civil society organizations (Center for Research and Development Resources-CIRD and ODS Paraguay Commission). 2.3 At least one government entity or partner has adopted an accelerator lab method: LabMTESS - Participatory Laboratory for the Formalization of Employment project was carried out in collaboration with the technical team of the Employment Observatory of the Ministry of Labor, Employment and Social Security, A team of consultants works closely with ministry professionals who completed a learning cycle on access to social security for informal workers within the construction sector. 2.4 At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects: Paraguay’s CO has 3 large portfolios including: Democratic Governance, Inclusive Development and Sustainable Development, in addition to cross-cutting areas such as Comms, Monitoring and Evaluation, HR and Gender. During 2020 and with many restrictions due to the health crisis, we managed to define 2 frontier challenges for the AccLab: 1) Formalization and Business Innovation and 2) Dialogue, Transparency and Citizen Participation. 1) We accompany the process of institutional strengthening and technical capacity of the San Francisco Neighborhood Recyclers Association, which is part of the work developed by the Asuncion Green City of the Americas (Sustainable Development CO Portfolio) 2) Methodological support for the strategic planning of the Paraguayan Evaluation Network (ORID Framework) 3) Infodemia Challenge: contest for students of the communication career on methodologies for identification of fake news about covid, led by the offices communication team and financed by the IDB. The AccLab colaborated in the contest and proposal workshops design and the implementation of the winning proposal. 4) During 2020, face-to-face and virtual training was carried out for the entire CO on: solution mapping, hypothesis design, collective intelligence and human-centered design. These workshops were facilitated by members of the AccLab
Output 3:
3.1 The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network. 48 interaction per year: One a week for Drop-In calls and biweekly calls by role (solution mappers, explorers, and experimenters) 3.2 25% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. 1) Solutions Mapping; 2) Human Centered Design; 3) Sensemaking; 4) Collective intelligence; 5) Randomized Controlled Trials; 6) Co-creation ; 7) Prototyping
3.3 The Accelerator Lab Networks work is featured at least 3 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account: We are constantly sharing progress on the different Acclab learning cycles through the CO social networks (twitter, facebook, instagram and linkedin) including: blogs, field activities, and presentations also sharing interviews to the Lab members in the local press and press releases. 3.4 Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 5 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem: Some of the strategies developed in order to increase the reach of our social media publications are: reposted from CO UNDP accounts and strategic allies in our projets and tag institutions, organizations and main collaborators in each publication, of which we could list: • Private Sector: Pacto Global, Ernest&Young • National Government: National Innovation Strategy (ENI), Ministry of Labor (MTESS), Ministry of Industry and Commerce (MIC), ODS National Commission; Ministry of Heath, National Science and technology Commission • Other UN Agencies: ILO, UN Development, UNICEF, Global AccLab Network • Civil Society:, CIRD, Paraguay Ahora, Teletón • Recognized Professionals: Mariana Salgado (Argentina-Finland), Daniel Aldrich (USA), Cyrus Samii (EGAP), David Riveros (Local NGO, Reaccion)
